coredata.dc:title: An ultra-thin composite electrolyte with vertical aligned Li ion transport pathways for all-solid-state lithium metal battery
coredata.dc:creator: Chen, Xiaobin
Liao, Wenchao
Chen, Dazhu
Huang, Yanfei
Liu, Chen
coredata.dc:description: All-solid-state lithium metal batteries employing composite electrolytes can fundamentally settle the safety issues of commercial liquid electrolytes. However, the thick thickness and low ionic conductivity as well as unregulated ion transport of current composite electrolytes pose great obstacles in further promoting their applicability and compatibility with Li metal anode. Herein, an ultra-thin composite electrolyte with vertical aligned Li ion transport pathways is rationally designed via filling polyethylene glycol-perfluoropolyether polymer electrolyte into the nanochannels of an alumina template via vacuum infusion and in-situ polymerization. The strong Lewis acid-base effect that existed between ions and composite electrolytes can construct numerous fast channels for Li+ transport. A restrained vertical direction of ion immigration can facilitate the uniform deposition of Li+ on metallic Li anode. The shortened Li ion conductive distance and superior electrolyte/electrode interfaces contribute to the improved electrochemical performance of the assembled solid-state batteries. An ionic conductivity of 1.21 × 10−4 S cm−1 and a transference number of 0.37 at room temperature are achieved for the designed composite electrolytes, which is superior to those of the conventional composite electrolytes reinforced with Al2O3 or garnet nanoparticles. The corresponding Li symmetrical cell can stably work for over 1200 h without short-circuit and the LiFePO4 || Li full cell exhibits a high initial discharge capacity of 164.8 mAh g−1 with capacity retention of 93.7 % after 100 cycles with a coulombic efficiency close to 100 %. This work offers an effective tactic to develop ultra-thin composite electrolytes for high-performance all-solid-state lithium metal batteries.

Ultra-thin
Composite polymer electrolytes

ce:caption.ce:simple-para: Synthesis and structural characterization of the PPAA-CPE. (a) Schematic illustration of the synthesis route of PPAA-CPE. (b) Optical photographs of PPAA-CPE before and after UV curing. (c) FTIR spectra of PEG-DMA, PFPE-DMA and PEG-PFPE. (d) Top-view and (e) cross-section SEM image of AAO template. (f) Top-view SEM image of PPAA-CPE, and (g) cross-section SEM image with (h–j) corresponding EDS mapping of PPAA-CPE.

(a) DSC and (b) TG curves of various electrolytes used in this work. (c) Impedance plots, and (d) Arrhenius plots of the PEG-PFPE and its corresponding composite electrolyte©(e) Comparison of the ionic conductivities of the as-obtained electrolytes at room temperature. (f) LSV curves of the PEG-PFPE electrolyte and PPAA-CPE. (g–i) Li+ transference numbers of PEG, PEG-PFPE electrolyte and PPAA-CPE.

Electrochemical performance of different electrolytes using LiFePO4 || Li battery. (a) Rate performance of PPAA-CPE at 60 °C. (b) Galvanostatic charge-discharge curves of PPAA-CPE with different rates at 60 °C. (c) Cycling performances of the designed electrolytes at 0.2 C. (d) Cycling performance of PPAA-CPE at 2 C.

Comparison of cycling performances and enlarged curve details of symmetrical Li cells assembled with (a) PEG-PFPE electrolyte, (b) PPLL electrolyte, (c) PPAL electrolyte, and (d) PPAA electrolyte at a current density of 0.1 mA cm−2 with an area capacity of 0.1 mAh cm−2 at 60 °C. SEM images of Li metal surface after Li plating/stripping of (e) PEG-PFPE electrolyte, (f) PPLL electrolyte, (g) PPAL electrolyte, and (h) PPAA electrolyte.

(a) Dimensional thermal stability of commercial PP separator and PPAA-CPE at setting temperatures of 25 °C–200 °C. (b) Combustion tests of PEG-PFPE and PPAA-CPE membranes. (c) Practical application tests of LiFePO4 || PPAA || Li cell.

head.ce:title: An ultra-thin composite electrolyte with vertical aligned Li ion transport pathways for all-solid-state lithium metal battery

ce:affiliation.ce:textfn: Guangdong Research Center for Interfacial Engineering of Functional Materials, Shenzhen Key Laboratory of Polymer Science and Technology, College of Materials Science and Engineering, Shenzhen University, Shenzhen, 518060, PR China

sa:affiliation.sa:organization: Guangdong Research Center for Interfacial Engineering of Functional Materials
Shenzhen Key Laboratory of Polymer Science and Technology
College of Materials Science and Engineering

ce:affiliation.ce:source-text: Guangdong Research Center for Interfacial Engineering of Functional Materials, Shenzhen Key Laboratory of Polymer Science and Technology, College of Materials Science and Engineering, Shenzhen University, Shenzhen 518060, PR China

ce:footnote.ce:note-para: These authors contributed equally to this work.

ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para: All-solid-state lithium metal batteries employing composite electrolytes can fundamentally settle the safety issues of commercial liquid electrolytes. However, the thick thickness and low ionic conductivity as well as unregulated ion transport of current composite electrolytes pose great obstacles in further promoting their applicability and compatibility with Li metal anode. Herein, an ultra-thin composite electrolyte with vertical aligned Li ion transport pathways is rationally designed via filling polyethylene glycol-perfluoropolyether polymer electrolyte into the nanochannels of an alumina template via vacuum infusion and in-situ polymerization. The strong Lewis acid-base effect that existed between ions and composite electrolytes can construct numerous fast channels for Li+ transport. A restrained vertical direction of ion immigration can facilitate the uniform deposition of Li+ on metallic Li anode. The shortened Li ion conductive distance and superior electrolyte/electrode interfaces contribute to the improved electrochemical performance of the assembled solid-state batteries. An ionic conductivity of 1.21 × 10−4 S cm−1 and a transference number of 0.37 at room temperature are achieved for the designed composite electrolytes, which is superior to those of the conventional composite electrolytes reinforced with Al2O3 or garnet nanoparticles. The corresponding Li symmetrical cell can stably work for over 1200 h without short-circuit and the LiFePO4 || Li full cell exhibits a high initial discharge capacity of 164.8 mAh g−1 with capacity retention of 93.7 % after 100 cycles with a coulombic efficiency close to 100 %. This work offers an effective tactic to develop ultra-thin composite electrolytes for high-performance all-solid-state lithium metal batteries.

ce:data-availability.ce:para: Data will be made available on request.

ce:section.ce:para: Owing to the depletion of fossil energy and worsening environmental issues, safe and eco-friendly electrical storage systems are greatly required [1]. Thereinto, lithium-ion batteries (LIBs) have been widely applied in the areas of portable devices and electric vehicles. Unfortunately, the conventional LIBs almost reach their ceiling of energy density (250 Wh kg−1), which no longer meets the demand of higher energy density for the rapid development of next-generation storage devices, especially electric vehicles (≥300 Wh kg−1). Thus, exploiting advanced or altering the current existing battery materials (including electrodes and electrolytes) to enhance the overall cell energy density has become an urgent target. To settle this issue, employing Li metal anode with ultra-high theoretical specific capacity (3860 mAh g−1) and the lowest electrode potential (−3.04 V versus the standard hydrogen electrode) has proved to be a promising strategy for realizing the high-energy-density lithium batteries [2]. Nevertheless, Li metal anode can cause rapid capacity fading and safety hazards due to the adverse chemical reactions between active Li metal and liquid electrolyte [3]. A replacement of liquid electrolytes with nonflammable and stable solid electrolytes (SEs) can be adopted to conquer this problem since the SEs possess higher thermal and electrochemical stability, as well as good mechanical strength [4].

Although solid electrolytes promise the safety of all-solid-state Li metal batteries (ASSLMBs) to a large extent, SEs usually need to maintain large thicknesses (around 100 μm or even 500 μm) to ensure the required mechanical strength [5], which is thicker than that of commercial separator, thereby reducing the potential of achieving high gravimetric/volumetric energy density of SSLMBs. Moreover, the thick electrolyte would also adversely influence its internal resistance and ion conduction ability. Thus, exploring ultrathin electrolytes is imperative in developing high-energy density SSLMBs to avoid the aforementioned issues. Presently, the in-situ synthesis of polymer is the most common strategy to fabricate ultrathin electrolytes, however, the inferior mechanical property of the obtained polymer electrolyte would result in poor cell performance [6]. In contrast, the incorporation of inorganic components in the polymer is a good practice that enhances ionic conductivity without sacrificing the flexibility of the polymer electrolyte [7]. To date, polymer-based composite electrolytes (CPEs) composed of various ceramic fillers (e.g. SiO2, Al2O3, Li7La3Zr2O12, Li6.4La3Zr1.4Ta0.6O12) and polymer matrixes have been studied extensively [8,9]. However, the ionic conductivities of most CPEs can only be enhanced to ∼10−5 S cm−1 at room temperature due to the limited reduced crystallinity of polymer matrix and Lewis acid-base effect between Li-ion and ceramic fillers.

Different from the incorporation of fillers, three-dimensional (3D) ceramic skeletons for CPEs can avoid agglomeration and construct a more continuous and compact structure, which can be favorable to the thermal stability, electrochemical stability, and ionic conductivity of CPEs. Yan et al. [10] fabricated a self-supporting 3D porous LATP skeleton filled with polyethylene glycol methyl ether acrylate. However, even if the common 3D structure can generally endow electrolytes with high ionic conductivity, the unordered space in the 3D structure may facilitate uneven Li deposition. To solve this problem, 3D skeletons with vertical structures have been attempted. The vertical configuration can induce the Li+ to conduct in a specific direction, which contributes to uniform ion deposition and effectively shortens the transmission distance of Li+ between cathode and anode, therefore effectively inhibiting the dendrite growth and significantly boosting the ionic conductivity. Zha et al. [11] fabricated a LAGP skeleton with a vertical structure using the ice-template method, which was then filled with succinonitrile (SN)/LiTFSI to obtain a CPE. However, the passivation reaction between SN and Li metal anode may lead to an unstable electrolyte/electrode interface. Although other methods like the wood template and electric field-oriented method are also adopted to construct vertical structures for ionic conduction, the fabrication processes are complicated to operate yet still cannot obtain dense skeletons [12,13]. Thus, constructing an internal flawless vertical configuration for CPEs with ultrathin thickness in a facile way, would potentially lead to high ion transport ability, high energy density, and safe solid-state lithium batteries.

In this work, an ultrathin composite electrolyte (PPAA-CPE) with vertical channels and continuous ceramic/polymer interfaces is developed by filling polyethylene glycol-perfluoropolyether (PEG-PFPE) polymer electrolyte into the nanochannels of an alumina (AAO) template via vacuum infusion and in-situ polymerization. The commercial AAO templates with stable and dense vertical skeleton as well as tunable thickness are conducive to construct ultrathin CPEs [14]. In our designed structure, a strong Lewis acid-base effect that existed between ions and composite electrolytes can construct numerous fast channels for Li+ transport. Moreover, ion-insulated AAO as a vertical inorganic template cannot inherently conduct Li+, which can ensure a specific vertical direction for fast Li+ conduction and specific areas for uniform Li+ deposition, so that the conductive distance between electrodes is greatly shortened, and a more stable electrolyte/Li metal anode interface is formed to suppress the dendrite growth. As a result, PPAA-CPE shows a superior ionic conductivity of 1.21 × 10−4 S cm−1 at room temperature, which is 24 times higher than PEG-PFPE electrolyte and about 10 times higher than CPEs using LLZTO and Al2O3 nanoparticles as inorganic fillers. Besides, the Li symmetrical cell using PPAA-CPE exhibits outstanding stability, running stably for up to 1200 h. Meanwhile, the LiFePO4 || Li full cell based on PPAA-CPE shows a high discharge capacity of 164.8 mAh g−1 with capacity retention of 93.7 % after 100 cycles at 0.2 C and 60 °C. In addition to prominent electrochemical performance, AAO inorganic template also endows PPAA-CPE with outstanding thermal stability and safety performance. These above results significantly demonstrate the superior comprehensive performance of an advanced ultrathin CPE with vertical structure, including outstanding ionic conductivity and cycling stability, which exhibits the potential to be a promising electrolyte for developing high-performance safe ASSLMBs.

We first designed a PEG-PFPE polymer electrolyte by crosslinking PEG-DMA with PFPE-DMA to ameliorate the Li-ion transference number of conventional PEG, since perfluoropolyether (PFPE) has been proven to be a single ion conducting polymer electrolyte [15]. The successful synthesis of PFPE-DMA using PFPE-OH and methacryloyloxyethyl isocyanate (IEM) was proved by 19F NMR and FTIR spectra analysis. As shown in Fig. S1a, the 19F NMR signals were detected from the as-prepared PFPE-DMA sample: the distinct peaks at −52 ppm/-55 ppm, −77.5 ppm/-79.5 ppm, and −88 ppm/-91 ppm can be indexed to –CF2O-, –CF2-CH2O- and –CF2-CF2-O- respectively, which is consistent with the spectrum of PFPE-DMA reference [16]. Furthermore, the FTIR spectra of PFPE-OH and PFPE-DMA are also presented in Fig. S1b. Before the reaction, PFPE-OH has no peaks appear at 1750 cm−1, while the PFPE-DMA synthesized by the reaction of PFPE-OH and IEM shows an obvious characteristic peak at 1750 cm−1 corresponding to the CC bond of methacrylate groups from DMA, which further demonstrates that DMA groups are successfully bonded to PFPE-OH. In addition, an occurrence of cross-linking reactions in the PFPE-DMA solution was further proved by the curing of the solution under UV light with the catalysis of 0.1 wt% 1-hydroxycyclohexyl phenyl ketone (HCPK). The as-prepared PFPE-DMA solution was used to constitute cross-linking network with PEG-DMA for the in-situ polymerization of PEG-PFPE in the AAO template and the polymerization routine is shown in Fig. S2.

Fig. 1 a illustrates the synthesis procedure of PPAA-CPE. The composition ratios are recorded in Table S1 and Table S2. Firstly, the catalyst, LiTFSI, PEG-DMA, and PFPE-DMA solution were mixed and stirred to prepare the PEG-PFPE-LiTFSI precursor solution. It should be noted that different percentages of PFPE-DMA in the precursor can significantly affect the impedance of PEG-PFPE electrolytes. As shown in Fig. S3, with the increasing content of PFPE-DMA, the bulk impedances (Rb) of PEG-PFPE electrolytes enhance from 211 Ω to 4402 Ω at room temperature, leading to the descending ionic conductivities, which mainly on account of the relatively weak ion transport ability of PFPE. Thus, the volume ratio of 10: 1 (PEG-DMA to PFPE-DMA) with the smallest impedance is selected as the optimal formula for further use. Moreover, as shown in Figs. S4a and b, different molar ratios of LiTFSI to PEG-DMA also affect the ion conduction ability of PEG-PFPE electrolytes, and 18: 1 for EO: Li+ exhibits the highest ionic conductivity among all the samples. Then the PPAA-CPE was synthesized through the dropwise addition of PEG-PFPE precursor solution in a dried AAO template and subsequent UV curing. As displayed in Fig. 1b, milky PEG-PFPE solution was formed by evenly stirring the mixture composed of PEG-DMA and PFPE-DMA with a certain ratio and 0.1 wt% HCPK catalyst. After UV curing for 1 min, the PEG-PFPE solution turned from a fluid into a solid and stuck to the bottom of the glass bottle. To confirm the successful cross-linking of PEG-DMA and PFPE-DMA, FTIR spectra are collected as shown in Fig. 1c. It is clear that the peaks of PEG-DMA and PFPE-DMA at 1712.3 cm−1 corresponding to CC stretching vibration disappear after UV curing, demonstrating the successful formation of cross-linked PEG-PFPE through the proposed synthesis procedure [17]. The microstructure and morphology of the AAO template and as-prepared PPAA-CPE were characterized by scanning electron microscopy (SEM). According to Fig. 1d and e, the as-received AAO template shows a kind of honeycomb structure composed of many nanopores with a diameter of 200 nm and possesses a thickness of around 60 μm. The porous structure can function like an inorganic skeleton to hold the PEG-PFPE polymer electrolyte for the fabrication of inorganic-organic ultrathin CPE with better comprehensive performance. The nanopores of the AAO template were covered fully by the polymer electrolyte, with no obvious pores left as shown in Fig. 1f, and the cross-section SEM image of PPAA-CPE in Fig. 1g also indicates the full filling of PEG-PFPE in the nanochannels. The overall thickness of the CPE is ∼60 μm. The corresponding EDS elemental mapping images show the presence of elements C, O, and F distributed uniformly in Fig. 1h–j, reaffirming that porous channels of the AAO template were completely filled with PEG-PFPE polymer electrolyte.

The crystallinity of polymer matrix is related to the polymer segmental mobility and ion transport ability, which can be calculated from the DSC analysis (Fig. 2 a) [18]. As shown in Table S3, PPLL-CPE and PPAL-CPE display decreased crystallinities compared with the PEG-PFPE electrolyte in an obvious way thanks to the inorganic nanoparticle additives (10 wt% LLZTO/10 wt% Al2O3), which can effectively enlarge the amorphous area of CPEs and thus improve the ionic conductivities. But most importantly, PPAA-CPE shows the lowest crystallinity of 8.9 % among all the electrolytes, probably resulting from the hydrogen bonding interaction between the PEG-PFPE electrolyte with the AAO template in the curing process. To further investigate the thermal stability of the designed electrolytes, TGA tests were performed as shown in Fig. 2b. After incorporating PFPE-DMA, the cross-linked PEG-PFPE possesses a higher initial thermal decomposition temperature (T5%) of 303 °C which is obviously higher than that of PEG-DMA (283 °C) because of the cross-linked network structure formed by PEG-DMA and PFPE-DMA. The higher T5% demonstrates better thermal stability of PEG-PFPE compared with PEG-DMA.

An ideal solid-state electrolyte for high-performance SSBs should possess satisfactory ionic conductivity to ensure fast and uniform ion transport. The ionic conductivities of PEG-PFPE, PPAL, PPLL, and PPAA electrolytes were measured by electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS). In Fig. 2c, PEG-PFPE shows the highest Rb of as high as 4424 Ω, which resulted from the high crystallinity (Table S3). With the incorporation of LLZTO and Al2O3 inorganic nanoparticles, the value of Rb significantly decreased to 1173 Ω and 1003 Ω for PPLL and PPAL, respectively. But most notably, the value of Rb for ultrathin PPAA-CPE with an inorganic vertical channel skeleton is only 70 Ω at room temperature. Furthermore, PPAA-CPE also shows ultralow impedances at other temperatures besides room temperature as shown in Fig. S5. The impedance evidently decreased with the increase in temperature because of the improved ionic transport kinetic. The Arrhenius plots of different electrolytes are further exhibited in Fig. 2d. Owing to the lower crystallinity and a large amount of ion conductive pathways provided by inorganic components, the activation energy (Ea) for each CPE is distinctly lower than that of PEG-PFPE polymer electrolyte at 25 °C ∼ 80 °C. Most importantly, PPAA-CPE possesses the lowest Ea, suggesting that the AAO template provides numerous fast vertical conductive channels by which the performance of ionic conduction within PPAA-CPE can be further greatly enhanced and therefore contributes to high ionic conductivity. The ionic conductivities of different electrolytes are intuitively shown in Fig. 2e. PEG-PFPE electrolyte has a relatively low ionic conductivity of 5.0 × 10−6 S cm−1. After distributing LLZTO and Al2O3 nanoparticles in the PEG-PFPE polymer matrix, the room-temperature ionic conductivity increases to 1.0 × 10−5 S cm−1 and 1.4 × 10−5 S cm−1 respectively. Apart from traditional inorganic-organic composite reinforcement, extra fast vertical conductive channels brought by the AAO template greatly boost the ionic conductivity to 1.2 × 10−4 S cm−1, which is superior among all the electrolyte samples.

The electrochemical stabilities of PPAA-CPE and PEG-PFPE electrolytes were measured by linear sweep voltammetry (LSV) using Li || SS cells at room temperature (Fig. 2f). PEG-PFPE electrolyte shows a potential window of 5.0 V which is already better than most of the common polymer electrolytes because of the incorporation of high oxidation resistance of PFPE [19]. Even better, PPAA-CPE obtains superior electrochemical stability of approximately 5.5 V due to the addition of an inorganic AAO template, implying that the CPE can potentially match with the high-voltage cathodes for high-energy-density LMBs. The high Li+ transference number (
t
L i
+
) could effectively alleviate the concentration polarization within batteries and promote uniform deposition of Li+ that contributes to the suppression of lithium dendrites [20]. As shown in Fig. 2g, a low
t
L i
+
0f 0.17 is obtained in the conventional PEG electrolyte because apart from Li+ transport, anions (TFSI−) from lithium salt also tend to migrate by themselves in the PEG electrolyte. In contrast, PFPE is conducive to anion immobilization for more efficient Li+ transport [19]. Consequently, the
t
L i
+
of the PEG-PFPE electrolyte is increased to 0.35, which is about twice as much as the PEG electrolyte. After incorporating the AAO template, the transference number can be further enhanced to 0.37, probably owing to the Lewis acid-base interaction between the hydrogen bonds of alumina oxide and lithium ions [21].

The improved ionic conductivity and Li transference number of the designed composite electrolyte can be theoretically interpreted from the following explanation: Firstly to PEG-PFPE, Li+ in PEG-PFPE electrolyte mainly transport between PEG chains by the combined action of ether oxygen bonds and EO segmental motion, but the segmental mobility in PEG-PFPE electrolyte is greatly restricted due to its highly cross-linked at room temperature after UV curing and thus leads to a low room-temperature ionic conductivity. In contrast, with the addition of LLZTO and Al2O3 nanoparticles, the crystallinity of the polymer matrix can be decreased and yield more free volume for the segmental motion of polymer chains. Except for polymer segments, the Li+ in PPLL can also move along the interface between LLZTO particles and polymer chains [22]. Therefore, the ionic conductivities of PPLL and PPAL CPEs can be improved to a certain extent (1.0 × 10−5 S cm−1 for PPLL and 1.4 × 10−5 S cm−1 for PPAL). Different from direct addition of normal inorganic particles, to further achieve better ionic conduction performance, PPAA-CPE is designed to shorten the ion conduction pathways in the vertical direction through an ionic inert AAO template, and consequently obtains a superior ion conduction performance [20].

All the aforementioned results reveal that PPAA-CPE possesses applicability in all-solid-state lithium metal batteries. The cells were assembled with the composite electrolytes using LiFePO4 as the cathode and Li metal as the anode. The rate performance in Fig. 3 a reveals that the cell using PPAA-CPE as an electrolyte delivers satisfactory average discharge capacities of 157.6 mAh g−1, 139.5 mAh g−1, 109.2 mAh g−1, and 80.7 mAh g−1 at 0.2 C, 0.5 C, 1.0 C, and 2.0 C, respectively. When the current density is reverted to 0.2 C, a high average specific capacity of 153.1 mAh g−1 is exhibited for PPAA-CPE, demonstrating good cycling stability and reversibility. On the contrary, as a result of the huge difference between PPAA-CPE and the other three kinds of electrolytes for ion conduction performance, PEG-PFPE, PPLL, and PPAL CPEs display worse rate performance than that of PPAA-CPE, especially under high current density (Fig. S6a). At a high rate of 2 C, PPAA-CPE still obtains an average specific discharge capacity of 80.7 mAh g−1, while PEG-PFPE, PPLL, and PPAL electrolytes show much lower specific capacities of 0.6 mAh g−1, 14.0 mAh g−1 and 19.5 mAh g−1, respectively.

Additionally, to further evaluate the electrochemical performance, the corresponding charge-discharge curves of LiFePO4 || Li batteries based on the electrolytes mentioned above are exhibited in Fig. 3b and Figs. S6b–d, respectively. The prepared cell using PPAA-CPE as an electrolyte exhibits a smooth charge and discharge voltage profiles at various current densities, while the other three kinds of electrolytes all display abnormal charge-discharge curves with severe polarization under higher current densities, indicating the good interfacial compatibility between PPAA-CPE and electrodes. The inferior performance of PEG-PFPE polymer electrolyte is probably caused by its poor ionic conductivity and electrochemical stability. For PPLL and PPAL polymer-based CPEs, the inevitable agglomeration of ceramic particles could hinder the ion transport within the electrolytes and adversely affect the physical contact with electrodes. The long cycling performance is tightly relevant to the ion conduction and electrolyte/electrode interfacial stability in a battery. Consequently, as shown in Fig. 3c, the LiFePO4 || Li cell with PPAA-CPE delivers the highest discharge capacity of 164.8 mAh g−1 which is close to the theoretical capacity of LiFePO4 (170 mAh g−1), suggesting that PPAA-CPE is endowed with high capacity by its superior ionic conductivity. Meanwhile, the best capacity retention of 93.7 % is obtained after 100 cycles under 0.2 C at 60 °C and the coulombic efficiency of the LiFePO4 || PPAA || Li maintains almost 100 % during the whole cycling. The results above adequately demonstrate that PPAA-CPE is equipped with prominent properties of ionic conduction and interfacial stability. However, the highest discharge capacities of PEG-PFPE, PPLL, and PPAL are 122.3 mAh g−1, 129.7 mAh g−1, and 132.5 mAh g−1, respectively, which are much lower than that of PPAA-CPE. Their fast fading of discharge capacities is probably due to the low ion transport ability of CPEs and the uneven deposition of Li+ on the surface of the Li metal anode, thereby leading to the striking augment on interfacial impedance, which in turn gives rise to the continuous increasing polarization and attenuated capacity. Fortunately, benefiting from the uniform ion deposition promoted by the induced Li+ conduction in the vertical direction, PPAA-CPE owns a stable interface between the electrolyte and Li metal anode, which ensures the long-term cycling stability of the prepared battery even under high current density. As shown in Fig. 3d, at a high rate of 2 C, an outstanding capacity retention of 74.2 % was obtained by LiFePO4 || PPAA || Li cell after being cycled 200 times.

To characterize the stability of electrolytes against Li metal anode, Li symmetric cells using different electrolytes were assembled and tested under a current density of 0.1 mA cm−2 at 60 °C. As shown in Fig. 4 a, with a slowly increasing polarized voltage at the early stage, the polarization of Li || PEG-PFPE || Li cell starts to rapidly intensify after being cycled for 60 h, and eventually running less than 200 h. This result demonstrates that a worsening interface between PEG-PFPE electrolyte and Li metal was aroused during the Li stripping/plating processes, which is probably caused by the detrimental side reaction on the interface. Furthermore, the rapid cell fail phenomenon is also observed for Li symmetrical cells using || PPLL and PPAL in Fig. 4b and c, suggesting that the inorganic nanoparticles incorporated electrolytes cannot effectively regulate the Li+ deposition behavior on Li metal anode though they can improve the ionic conductivity to a certain extent. In sharp contrast, Fig. 4d shows that Li symmetrical cell using PPAA-CPE can run stably for up to 1200 h, revealing the superior interfacial stability between PPAA-CPE and Li metal anode. Moreover, to further investigate the Li stripping/plating behaviors, SEM was conducted to observe the surface morphology of disassembled Li metal electrodes after being cycled with different electrolytes. As shown in Fig. 4e–g, plenty of dead lithium and mossy lithium dendrites accumulated on the surface of Li metal, accompanied by many obvious cracks, showing rough and uneven surfaces for PEG-PFPE, PPLL, and PPAL electrolytes. On the contrary, the surface of Li metal in Li || PPAA || Li cell displays an extremely dense and smooth surface without any obvious lithium dendrites and fragments of dead lithium, further confirming that the introduction of AAO template with vertical channels in PPAA-CPE can bring a great improvement on the stability of the interface between the electrolyte and Li metal anode. Specifically, given that the PEG-PFPE polymer electrolyte and AAO template both cannot react with Li metal anode to generate interface-stable SEI, which means the formation of stable PPAA/Li metal interface is unrelated to SEI, the practical reason for superior interfacial stability is that the ion-conductive PEG-PFPE polymer electrolyte is separated by the vertical nanochannels, ion transport pathways are limited and Li ions are induced to deposition in specific areas through vertical channels, therefore stabilizing the interface between the electrolyte and Li metal anode.

Thermal safety performance is of great importance to the practical application of rechargeable lithium batteries, the dimensional thermal stability and combustion tests were conducted to examine the thermal stability and flammability of as-obtained electrolyte membranes. As displayed in Fig. 5 a, a slight dimensional shrinkage for the commercial PP separator emerges at 80 °C and a serious curl occurs under 120 °C, which can cause a short-circuit of the battery. When the temperature keeps going up to 160 °C and 200 °C, the PP separator starts to melt, indicating the poor dimensional stability of PP separator at high temperatures. However, for the PPAA-CPE membrane, the outstanding thermal stability is demonstrated by its almost constant shape under the temperature ranging from 25 °C to 200 °C. To further investigate their thermal safety performance, the electrolyte membranes with the same specification were both directly ignited by alcohol flame. A violent burning of the PEG-PFPE electrolyte membrane can be clearly seen in Fig. 5b, which was almost burned out within 5 s, indicating its high flammability. By contrast, the PPAA-CPE membrane under direct flame cannot be burned out over 11 s, suggesting its excellent thermal safety. Moreover, Fig. 5c shows that the lighted LED lamp and well-working electronic chronometer strongly demonstrate that the assembled solid-state lithium metal battery using PPAA-CPE possesses great potential in practical application.

In this work, an ultrathin composite electrolyte (PPAA-CPE) with vertical Li+ conduction pathways is rationally designed using an AAO template filled with PEG-PFPE polymer electrolyte to simultaneously improve the ionic conductivity, Li-ion transference number, and electrolyte/Li metal anode interface stability. The rapid Li+ conductive nanochannels and Lewis acid-base effect brought by the AAO template greatly enhance the ionic conductivity to 1.2 × 10−4 S cm−1, which is 24 times higher than that of the PEG-PFPE electrolyte. Meanwhile, the vertical channels also exert directional restriction on Li+ transport, promoting uniform Li ion deposition on the Li metal surface during cycling. As a result, Li symmetrical cell based on PPAA-CPE can run stably for 1200 h without obvious dendrite growth. The improved interface stability and Li-ion conduction ability contribute to a high initial discharge capacity of 164.8 mAh g−1 with superior capacity retention of 93.7 % after 100 cycles at 0.2 C for LiFePO4 || PPAA || Li cell, while the discharge capacity of PEG-PFPE, and other CPEs reinforced by LLZTO and Al2O3 nanoparticles, drops rapidly due to the interfacial deterioration. Furthermore, the excellent thermal safety of PPAA-CPE is fully confirmed under high-temperature storing and flame tests. The prominent performance of PPAA-CPE indicates that the proposed strategy is promising for high-performance safe ASSLMBs.

Xiaobin Chen: Investigation, Writing-Original Draft; Wenchao Liao: Methodology, Validation, Investigation; Dazhu Chen: Resources, Supervision; Yanfei Huang: Writing - Review & Editing, Supervision; Chen Liu: Conceptualization, Methodology, Writing - Original Draft, Writing - Review & Editing, Supervision, Funding acquisition.
